No, my landlord did not tell me of the deductions.

Yes, my landlord has my new address.
No, my landlord does not have my new address.

Did your landlord include actual receipts?

Yes, there were receipts included.
No, it was just an estimate
No, there were no estimates or receipts

Yes, I have a copy of the lease.
No, I do not have a copy of the lease to upload.

Great, thank you for the response. Did you sign a written lease?

Yes, I signed a written lease.
No, I did not sign a written lease.
Great. We will do our best to make this as easy as possible for you. Letâ€™s continue.

Yes, I have moved out.
No, I have not moved out.

If that's true, your landlord may not be able to deduct any money for repairs and you may be able to get your deposit back.

Looking at your situation, under the law, landlords typically need to return security deposits within 45 day of you moving out. But in some circumstances, landlords can hold on to security deposits. Let us see if any of those circumstances apply here.

Thank you, let's check together.

Please know that the law may provide for two times the security deposit for some violations, but this letter only asks for your original deposit amount back. If you want, you can edit this letter or write your own instead.

Let's proceed
Thank you for sharing. Let me check, when did you move out?

Thank you for telling me. Do you owe money to your landlord for any past-due rent? Under the law, your landlord may be able to deduct past-due rent from your deposit.

Yes, I owe my landlord money for past-due rent.
No, I do not owe any money for past-due rent.

Thank you for your helpful responses. Could you share if you have completely moved out?

Yes, I have completely moved out.
No, I have not moved out completely.

Thank you!

Thanks for letting us know. We will try our best to resolve your security deposit issues with your landlord as quickly as possible. Please bear with us. We can solve this together.
Thanks for using Rentervention!
That may be a problem for your landlord. Landlords need to tell you when they deduct a "reasonable amount" for repairs from your security deposit.

The law here is time-sensitive and your landlord needs to follow it in order to avoid hefty fines and other penalties. Let's walk through collecting facts together.

This is helpful. I see you're in Chicago.

We may be able to write a letter to your landlord requesting your security deposit back. Would you like to continue?

Yes, I would like to continue.

We truly care about you and your experiences. We know how challenging and stressful it can be when you have a problem with a landlord. Our goal is to help you and make this process as simple as possible for you. To start, we would first like to learn more about your issue. 

There's trouble with my security deposit.
I got an eviction notice.
My landlord won't fix problems in my apartment.

My landlord locked me out.

When did the tenant move out?
When did the tenant receive the estimate for repairs?
6 Units or less: There are no specific rules
7 or more units: The landlord must return the security deposit within 45 days after the tenants move out.
After the landlord provides the tenant with the statement of damages, the tenant has the right to appeal the damages.
After the tenant has moved out and returned the keys, the tenant must have given the landlord, in writing, the address where they want the landlord to mail the security deposit.
After the time expires for the landlord to return the tenant's security deposit:
Based on the scenario in the upper right hand corner, are you entitled to the retyurn of all or some of your security deposit from the landlord?
do not exceed the security deposit, the landlord must send the remaining balance of the security deposit to the tenant.
exceed the security deposit, the tenant must send the additional fees to the landlord.
For a building with 7 or more units, the landlord does not have to send the tenant a statement if they keep the security deposit because the tenant owed rent.
For a building with 7 or more units, the landlord must provide the tenant with receipts or an estimate for repairs to the property within 30 days after the tenant moves out.
Getting back a security deposit
Given the scenario, please use the FAQ below to determine how to answer the two following questions:
If so, what do you need to do to get your security deposit back?
If the damages

If the landlord can't show receipts for the damages, they must still provide an itemized list of the costs. They must provide any other evidence they have to show what they paid for repairs. They must explain why they cannot produce the receipts.
If the landlord fails to provide a mailing address or e-mail, the landlord is not responsible for providing the receipts or returning the security deposit.
If the tenant and landlord cannot reach an agreement on the amount of the security deposit returnd:
If the tenant does not appeal, the landlord must respond within 15 days providing additional evidence of the repairs.
If the tenant has not moved out
If the tenant has not provided the landlord their new address
If there are damages to the property:
If there is past-due rent

Normal wear and tear (including worn carpet edges, scuffed walls, and dirty countertops) does not warrant withholding a security deposit. However, any significant damages beyond reasonable wear and tear can result in the security deposit being withheld.
The letter can tell the landlord that they had 45 days to either return the security deposit or give the tenant a list of how the money was spent.
The tenant also needs to return all of the keys to the landlord after they move out.
The tenant can check the written lease, if there is one, to make sure they have followed all of the instructions for moving out.
The tenant can file a case in small claims court in the county where the unit was located or where the landlord lives.
the tenant can send a written demand letter by mail with a tracking number requesting the return of the deposit.
The tenant can sue their landlord to get back the amount of the security deposit that the landlord withheld, plus the costs of the lawsuit.
The tenant must have moved all of their items out from the unit and have cleaned the unit to recover their security deposit.
This includes all floors and surfaces, the refrigerator, the freezer, the oven, and all the bathrooms.
Under what conditions can a landlord keep a security deposit?
What can the tenant do if their landlord does not return the security deposit within the required time?
What can the tenant do if they do not agree with the written statement of damages?
What must the landlord show to prove damages?
When must a landlord return a tenant's security deposit?
